vpn_content_1: VPN stands for Virtual Private Network, which refers to a technology that securely transmits data over the Internet. By encrypting data and preventing data leakage during transmission, VPN can enhance security. With VPN, you can securely connect to the
vpn_content_2: internal Linux servers from outside the network
vpn_content_3: The following is a list of Linux server IP addresses that can be accessed via VPN:
vpn_content_4: You can also connect to other servers (e.g., Linux servers operated in research labs) via VPN from outside the network. If you would like to add servers that can be accessed via VPN, please contact the administrator.
vpn_otp_content_1: To connect to VPN, you need an OTP (One-Time Password). OTP is a system that generates a new password every time you connect to VPN to enhance security. Follow these steps to set up OTP.
vpn_otp_content_3: To set up OTP, you need an OTP app. Any app that supports the standard OTP protocol can be used, and the following apps are available:
vpn_otp_content_5: After installing the OTP app, you need to register the OTP for VPN connection. To generate OTP, click the button below, scan the QR code that appears in the popup window with the OTP app, and register the OTP.
vpn_otp_content_6-1: For security reasons, the QR code is displayed only once and will not be displayed again after the window is closed. Run the OTP app first and prepare to scan the QR code.
vpn_otp_content_6-2: OTP is already registered. To re-register OTP, click the button below to send a request email to the administrator.
vpn_openvpn_content_1: To connect to VPN, you need OpenVPN Connect. OpenVPN Connect is a VPN client app that can be used on various platforms such as Windows, MacOS, Android, iOS, and ChromeOS. The OpenVPN Connect app can be downloaded from the following link:
vpn_openvpn_content_3: After downloading and installing OpenVPN Connect, you need a VPN configuration file. Click the button below to download and run the VPN configuration file, and OpenVPN Connect app will run automatically and the configuration will be added.
vpn_openvpn_content_5: Complete the setup by entering the following connection information:
vpn_openvpn_content_8: If you frequently connect to VPN, it may be convenient to save your password.
vpn_connect_content_1: Once the VPN setup is complete, run the OpenVPN Connect app and connect to the VPN server. You must enter the 6-digit number generated by the OTP each time you connect.
linux_content_1: You can use various services such as SSH connection through the Linux server.
linux_content_2: The following is a list of Linux servers currently in operation:
linux_content_3: The servers can be accessed via SSH within the network, and can be accessed via SSH after connecting to VPN from outside the network. All user data is stored on a central NAS, so you can use the same user environment on all servers.
linux_connect_title: How to connect to Linux server
linux_connect_intro: You can connect to the Linux server via a terminal (SSH) or Visual Studio Code.
linux_connect_content_6: Open a terminal: Windows Terminal on Windows, Terminal on macOS, or a terminal emulator on Linux.
linux_connect_content_9: When a message asking about the server's trustworthiness appears for the first time, enter 'yes'.
linux_connect_content_10: Enter the password to complete the connection.
linux_connect_content_11: How to connect using Visual Studio Code
linux_connect_content_13: Click the Extensions icon on the left sidebar, search for the Remote - SSH extension, and install it.
linux_connect_content_14: Click the >< icon at the bottom left of the VSCode window (see below).
linux_connect_content_16: Click + Add New SSH Host..., and enter the following:
linux_connect_content_17: Press Enter again to add the server to your default SSH settings.
linux_connect_content_19: Click the added server IP to connect.
linux_connect_content_20: When prompted to select an operating system, select 'Linux'.
linux_connect_content_21: Enter the password to complete the connection.
linux_ssh-key_title: How to connect to Linux servers using SSH key
linux_ssh-key_content_1: User computers are vulnerable to hacking, especially when passwords are frequently leaked during the process of entering passwords. Using SSH key authentication to connect to Linux servers allows you to connect without entering a password, making it more convenient and secure. We recommend following the steps below to set up SSH key authentication.
linux_ssh-key_content_3: Open PowerShell on Windows, or Terminal on macOS or Linux.
linux_ssh-key_content_4: Enter the following command to generate an SSH key:
linux_ssh-key_content_5: Answer all questions with Enter to generate an SSH key. This will create a .ssh directory under your home directory (e.g., /home/username for Linux, C:\Users\username for Windows, /Users/username for macOS), and the following two files will be created inside it.
linux_ssh-key_content_8: The generated private key file (id_rsa file) should never be shared with others and should be stored securely.
linux_ssh-key_content_9: Copy the public key to the server
linux_ssh-key_content_10: Open the generated public key file id_rsa.pub with a text editor such as Visual Studio Code and copy the contents.
linux_ssh-key_content_11: Connect to the Linux server and add the copied public key to the authorized_keys file in the .ssh directory under the home directory. If the .ssh directory and authorized_keys file do not exist, create them.
linux_ssh-key_content_12: Now, try connecting to the server. You will be able to connect without entering a password.
linux_ssh-key_content_13: Using SSH key authentication allows you to connect to Linux servers without entering a password. SSH key authentication increases security and is convenient because you do not have to enter a password every time.
